raw_text:
US hacker breaks into T-Mobile
 
 A man is facing charges of hacking into computers at the US arm of mobile phone firm T-Mobile.
 
 The Californian man, Nicholas Lee Jacobsen, was arrested in October. Mr Jacobsen tried at least twice to hack T-Mobile's network and took names and social security numbers of 400 customers, said a company spokesman. The arrest came a year after T-Mobile uncovered the unauthorised access. The US Secret Service has been investigating the case. "T-Mobile has stringent procedures in place where we monitor for suspicious activity so that limited his activities and we were able to take corrective action immediately," Peter Dobrow, a T-Mobile spokesperson said. It is thought that Mr Jacobsen's hacking campaign took place over at least seven months during which time he read e-mails and personal computer files, according to court records.
 
 Although Mr Jacobsen, 21, managed to get hold of some data, it is thought he failed to get customer credit card numbers which are stored on a separate computer system, said Mr Dobrow. T-Mobile confirmed that the US Secret Service was also looking into whether the hacker accessed photos that T-Mobile subscribers had taken with their camera phones. The Associated Press agency reported that Mr Jacobsen also read personal files on the Secret Service agent who was apparently investigating the case. A Los Angeles grand jury indicted Mr Jacobsen with intentionally accessing a computer system without authorisation and with the unauthorised impairment of a protected computer between March and October 2004. He is currently on bail. T-Mobile is a subsidiary company of Deutsche Telekom and has about 16.3 million subscribers in the US.
llama3.2:1b: A Californian man, Nicholas Lee Jacobsen, was arrested for hacking into T-Mobile's network in October. The incident occurred at least seven months prior to his arrest. Jacobsen accessed customer data, including names and social security numbers, of around 400 customers. He attempted to hack again but failed to obtain credit card numbers. A grand jury indicted Jacobsen with unauthorized access to a computer system.
llama3.2:3b: A 21-year-old Californian man, Nicholas Lee Jacobsen, was arrested for hacking into T-Mobile's network and accessed data from at least 400 customers over seven months. He took names and social security numbers but failed to get credit card information or access photos taken with camera phones. Jacobsen read e-mails and personal files of a Secret Service agent investigating the case, leading to a Los Angeles grand jury indictment for unauthorized computer access and impairment of protected computers between March and October 2004.
gemma2:2b: Nicholas Lee Jacobsen, a Californian man, was arrested for hacking into T-Mobile's network. He accessed personal data of at least 400 customers, including names and social security numbers, over seven months. The Secret Service is also investigating if he accessed photos taken by T-Mobile subscribers using their camera phones and potentially compromised a Secret Service agent who was investigating the case. He has been indicted on charges of unauthorized computer access and impairing protected computer systems.
qwen2.5:0.5b: A man named Nicholas Lee Jacobsen, 21, was arrested by the US Secret Service for hacking into computers at his mobile phone company, T-Mobile. He tried to access customers' personal information like social security numbers and their contact details, but failed to get them. The arrest came after a report that T-Mobile had been monitoring his activities for suspicious activity. Jacobsen is currently on bail.
qwen2.5:1.5b: A California man, Nicholas Lee Jacobsen, aged 21, hacked into T-Mobile's network to obtain customer names and social security numbers but did not steal credit card information or access sensitive photos. He was arrested for attempted unauthorized computer access from October 2004 to October 2005, following a year-long investigation by the US Secret Service.
qwen2.5:3b: A man, Nicholas Lee Jacobsen, aged 21, was arrested for hacking into T-Mobile's computers in California. The hacker attempted to gain access at least twice, compromising personal data of around 400 customers including names and social security numbers. This incident occurred a year after T-Mobile discovered unauthorized access. Investigations by the US Secret Service revealed that the attack spanned over seven months during which Jacobsen accessed emails and personal files. It is believed he did not obtain customer credit card details, though it's suspected he viewed photos taken with camera phones. The Associated Press reported Jacobsen also read files of the investigating secret service agent. Jacobsen was indicted for intentionally accessing a computer system without authorization in March to October 2004 and remains on bail. T-Mobile, now a subsidiary of Deutsche Telekom, has approximately 16.3 million subscribers in the US.
opencoder:1.5b:
US hacker breaks into T-Mobile
 
 A man faces charges of hacking into computers at the US arm of mobile phone firm T-mobile.
 
 T-Mobile, after uncovering unauthorized access, is investigating the case involving Mr Jacobsen, a California man who has been engaged in hacking attempts on his computer systems. The former was found near a network access point operated by T-mobile; it reportedly included several thousand users from different parts of the US, and during periods of heightened suspicion.
 
 According to court records, the former was accessed almost two times within one year and at least seven months when he read e-mail messages and personal files. The US Secret Service is investigating the case, confirming that a stringent monitoring policy exists that alerts officials if suspicious activity is detected. Mr Jacobsen, 21, managed to gain access to some data but failed to access credit card numbers stored on a separate computer system.

 According to the T-mobile company, they have also been monitoring photos taken with their camera phones from subscribers' accounts and read personal files shared by those phones, though this investigation hasn't yet been formally announced.
 
 A Los Angeles grand jury indicted Mr Jacobsen for intentionally accessing a computer without authorization, and also with the impairment of a protected computer between March and October 2004. He is currently on bail.
  
 The company has about 16 million subscribers in the US, marking a significant milestone for T-mobile's growth.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary should be: A man is facing charges of hacking into computers at the US arm of mobile phone firm T-Mobile. The Californian man, Nicholas Lee Jacobsen, was arrested in October for allegedly trying to hack T-Mobile's network and taking names and social security numbers of 400 customers. Mr Jacobsen tried at least twice to hack T-Mobile's network and took names and social security numbers of 400 customers, said a company spokesman. The arrest came a year after T-Mobile uncovered the unauthorised access. The US Secret Service has been investigating the case. "T-Mobile has stringent procedures in place where we monitor for suspicious activity so that limited his activities and we were able to take corrective action immediately," Peter Dobrow, a T-Mobile spokesperson said. It is thought that Mr Jacobsen's hacking campaign took place over at least seven months during which time he read e-mails and personal computer files, according to court records.

The summary should be: Although Mr Jacobsen, 21, managed to get hold of some data, it is thought he failed to get customer credit card numbers which are stored on a separate computer system, said T-Mobile's spokesperson. The Associated Press agency reported that Mr Jacobsen also read personal files on the Secret Service agent who was apparently investigating the case. A Los Angeles grand jury indicted Mr Jacobsen with intentionally accessing a computer system without authorisation and with the unauthorised impairment of a protected computer between March and October 2004. He is currently on bail. T-Mobile is a subsidiary company of Deutsche Telekom and has about 16.3 million subscribers in the US.

<think>
Okay, I need to summarize the given text. Let me read through it first.

So, the main event is a US hacker breaking into T-Mobile's arm. The man is Nicholas Lee Jacobsen, arrested around October, tried hacking twice, got names and social numbers of 400 customers. His campaign took over seven months, reading emails and files. They found e-mails and messages, which is interesting. The Secret Service is looking into camera footage and photos taken by T-Mobile's subscribers.

I should focus on the key points: his charges, his arrest date, what he did, the duration, and how they were detected. Also, mention T-Mobile's response, the agencies involved, and his current status.

Wait, does he read e-mails? That's a bit unusual but possible. The summary needs to be concise without adding details, just key ideas.
</think>

A US hacker broke into T-Mobile in October after the company uncovered unauthorized access. Nicholas Lee Jacobsen was arrested at least twice for hacking into customers' networks and obtained 400 customer data points. His campaign lasted seven months, reading emails and files. The Secret Service is investigating camera footage and photos taken by T-Mobile subscribers. He faced charges of hacking without authorization and impiling a protected computer system between March and October 2004. A Los Angeles grand jury indicted him on those charges. T-Mobile, a Deutsche Telekom subsidiary with about 16 million US subscribers, is linked to his case.
tinyllama:1.1b: A man was arrested for hacking into computers at the US arm of mobile phone firm T-Mobile, with investigators accusing him of taking names and social security numbers of around 400 customers. The unauthorized access occurred over a period of several months, leading to charges against Nicholas Lee Jacobsen. T-Mobile, who has over 16.3 million subscribers in the US, has taken action to correct any misinformation he may have accessed. However, Mr Jacobsen has allegedly failed to obtain credit card numbers stored on separate computer systems at T-Mobile. The company also confirmed that an investigation is underway into whether Mr Jacobsen accessed photos taken by T-Mobile subscribers' camera phones.
tinydolphin:1.1b: A US hacker, Nicholas Lee Jacobsen, was arrested for allegedly hacking into computers at the US arm of mobile phone firm T-Mobile. He was charged with intentional access to a computer system without authorization and unauthorized use of a protected computer between March and October 2004. This occurred when he attempted to hack into T-Mobile's network, which held customer credit card information. According to the US Secret Service, Jacobsen also accessed some personal files on one of its agents who was investigating his activities. T-Mobile has since taken measures to prevent future incidents and is cooperating with authorities in their investigation.
phi:2.7b: A man was arrested for trying to hack into computers at T-Mobile's US arm, accessing customers' information and social security numbers over several months before being caught. The suspect was charged with computer hacking and may have also accessed personal files of a US Secret Service agent. Although he did not obtain credit card numbers, the company is still investigating the case.
orca-mini:3b: A hacker named Nicholas Lee Jacobsen broke into T-Mobile's network in the United States. He obtained personal data from more than 400 customers, but failed to obtain customer credit card numbers. The US Secret Service was also investigating whether he accessed photos that T-Mobile subscribers had taken with their camera phones. The hacker faces charges of unauthorized access to a computer system and impairment of a protected computer. He is currently on bail.
hermes3:3b: US hacker Nicholas Lee Jacobsen tries, but fails, to breach T-Mobile; accessed customer names and social security numbers of 400 users over at least 7 months.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: A Californian man, Nicholas Lee Jacobsen, was arrested for hacking into T-Mobile's network in the US, attempting to access names and social security numbers of 400 customers. The arrest occurred a year after T-Mobile discovered unauthorized access. It is believed that Jacobsen's hacking campaign lasted seven months, during which he read emails and personal files. Although he accessed some data, he did not obtain customer credit card information or photos taken with camera phones. A grand jury indicted Jacobsen for intentionally accessing a computer system without authorization and for the unauthorized impairment of a protected computer between March and October 2004.
chatgpt-4o-latest: A Californian man, Nicholas Lee Jacobsen, was arrested for hacking into T-Mobile's US network, stealing names and social security numbers of 400 customers. His hacking campaign lasted at least seven months, during which he accessed emails and personal files but failed to obtain credit card details. The US Secret Service has been investigating, and a grand jury indicted him for unauthorized computer access. He also allegedly accessed files on a Secret Service agent. T-Mobile detected the breach early and took corrective action. Jacobsen is currently out on bail.
stablelm2:1.6b: A US hacker, Nicholas Lee Jacobsen, was arrested for attempting to hack into T-Mobile's network, stealing names and social security numbers from customers. Jacobsen allegedly conducted unauthorized access between March and October, with some data obtained but not credit card numbers. The US Secret Service is investigating if he accessed photos taken by T-Mobile subscribers' camera phones. Jacobsen faces charges of hacking and unauthorized impairment of a protected computer system. T-Mobile has stringent procedures in place to monitor suspicious activity.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Nicholas Lee Jacobsen, a 21-year-old from California, was arrested for hacking into T-Mobile's network, a U.S. subsidiary of Deutsche Telekom with approximately 16.3 million subscribers. In October, he attempted to breach the system at least twice, accessing names and social security numbers of around 400 customers over seven months. Despite his efforts, he did not obtain customer credit card information or photos taken by T-Mobile users with their camera phones. The U.S. Secret Service is investigating whether he also accessed these sensitive data types. Jacobsen's actions were detected and mitigated due to T-Mobile's stringent monitoring procedures. He was indicted on charges of intentional unauthorized computer access and impairment, and remains on bail following his arrest.
